data.source: Comparative Manifesto Project (CMP) party manifesto data
data.wave_or_subset: Elections in twenty established parliamentary democracies from 1945 to 1999
data.unit_of_analysis: Party system by country-election (dispersion within each party system); party positions for individual parties
data.notes: Two measures of the number of parties used (Sartori/Strøm relevance and Laakso-Taagepera effective number of parties). Policy space constructed via principal components analysis on CMP categories to form economic and social dimensions. Social dimension construction is less consensual than economic. Limited within-country variation in number/type of parties led to pooling across countries.

method.description: The study uses CMP manifesto data to estimate party positions in a two-dimensional policy space (economic and social) via principal components analysis. Party dispersion within each party system is measured as the distance between the most extreme parties along each dimension. The number of parties is measured using both a relevance count and the effective number of parties. The relationship between party dispersion and the number of parties is tested using OLS regressions with log-transformed variables, including electoral system type as a control. Analyses cover twenty parliamentary democracies from 1945 to 1999.
steps: Collect CMP-coded manifesto data for parties in twenty established parliamentary democracies (1945–1999).
Select positional CMP categories and construct two policy dimensions (economic and social) using principal components analysis.
Estimate party positions for each party on the two dimensions across country-elections.
Compute party system dispersion for each country-election as the distance between the most extreme parties along each dimension.
Measure the number of parties in each system using (a) Sartori/Strøm relevance count and (b) Laakso–Taagepera effective number of parties.
Classify electoral rules (e.g., SMDP vs PR) for each case.
Run OLS regressions of log dispersion on log number of parties, including electoral system type as a control.
Compare mean dispersion across two-party and multi-party systems and across electoral systems; assess statistical significance.
Evaluate whether dispersion increases with the number of parties and whether effects plateau around five parties.
method.models: OLS regression of log dispersion on log number of parties with electoral system control; principal components analysis to derive policy dimensions.
method.outcome_variable: Party dispersion along economic and social policy dimensions (distance between most extreme parties)
method.independent_variables: Number of parties (relevance count; effective number of parties), electoral system type (SMDP vs PR)
method.control_variables: Electoral system type; additional controls not stated

results.summary: Party dispersion increases with the number of parties but plateaus at around five parties. Once the number of parties is accounted for, electoral rules have no direct effect on dispersion. Two-party systems also exhibit non-trivial party distances, indicating parties do not fully converge to the median voter. Regression analyses with log-transformed variables show a positive, statistically significant relationship between the number of parties and dispersion in both economic and social dimensions, with modest explanatory power.
